questiontext.text:
A car travels at a constant speed of 53 km/hr. It encounters a retarding force (rolling resistance, air resistance etc) of 585 N.




At what power level does the engine deliver energy to the wheels to maintain the car's speed?

{1:NUMERICAL:=8.6:0.17225#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} kW

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
Power, $$P$$, can be defined as the amount of work, $$W$$, performed in a given time, $$t$$:

$$P=\frac{W}{t}$$


But work is also the product of force, $$F$$, and distance, $$x$$. Therefore:

$$P=\frac{F.x}{t}$$


But $$\frac{x}{t}$$ is equal to velocity, $$v$$. Therefore:

$$P=F.v=8.6 kW$$


(Don't forget to convert from km/hr to m/s)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from 'http://www.bbc.co.uk/staticarchive/9db0c22dbd8ec3a3c905dc8a854168e44c14035e.gif'

A car travels at a constant speed of 69 km/hr. It encounters a retarding force (rolling resistance, air resistance etc) of 561 N.




At what power level does the engine deliver energy to the wheels to maintain the car's speed?

{1:NUMERICAL:=10.8:0.21505#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} kW

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #99).

generalfeedback.text:
Power, $$P$$, can be defined as the amount of work, $$W$$, performed in a given time, $$t$$:

$$P=\frac{W}{t}$$


But work is also the product of force, $$F$$, and distance, $$x$$. Therefore:

$$P=\frac{F.x}{t}$$


But $$\frac{x}{t}$$ is equal to velocity, $$v$$. Therefore:

$$P=F.v=10.8 kW$$


(Don't forget to convert from km/hr to m/s)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
